Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A surprise, tie-breaking vote on a critical piece of legislation is happening in the next hour, and you must immediately contact the undecided representative.
Story:
I stared at my phone, heart pounding. Jake’s last message blinked on the screen: “I just wish you’d told me sooner.” Our weekend plans had gotten tangled up—he thought we were going hiking, but I’d mentioned a rally. Now he was upset, and I could feel the tension rising between us. I knew I should call him, talk it through, smooth things over before it grew into something bigger. That’s what a good girlfriend would do—resolve things, not let them fester.

But at the same time, my activist group’s chat was exploding. The statehouse was holding a surprise vote on the bill we’d been fighting for all year. The outcome was down to one undecided representative, and I was the only one with a personal connection. They needed me to call, to persuade, to make a difference—right now, before the vote.

I felt pulled in two directions, my phone heavy in my hand. Jake needed me. The movement needed me. My chest tightened as I tried to decide which call to make first, knowing that whichever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
